expanded_description: Chapter 5 Test explores energy principles through real-world scenarios, examining how energy transforms, why objects have certain energy properties, what forces do work, and where energy goes. Understanding these dynamics reveals the deep connections between forces, motion, energy transformations, and the fundamental principle that energy is never lost—only converted from one form to another.

core_concept.principle: Energy analysis of real situations requires identifying: (1) What types of energy are present (KE, PE, thermal, etc.), (2) How these energies change (increasing, decreasing, or constant), (3) What forces do work (and whether work is positive, negative, or zero), (4) Where energy goes when it transforms (mechanical → thermal, sound, deformation, etc.). Every physical scenario can be understood through energy accounting: track all energy forms, identify transformations, apply conservation (total energy constant).
core_concept.explanation:
Real-world energy analysis connects all Unit 5 concepts into comprehensive understanding. 

**Example 1: Airplane at constant altitude and speed** 
• Position: 90 m altitude (constant) → PE constant ($mgh$ unchanging) 
• Velocity: 120 m/s (constant) → KE constant ($\frac{1}{2}mv^2$ unchanging) 
• Total mechanical energy: constant (neither KE nor PE changing) 
• Forces: Engine thrust forward, air drag backward (equal—balanced forces), weight down, lift up (equal—balanced) 
• Work by forces: Engine does positive work, drag does equal negative work → net work = 0 → no KE change ✓ 
• Energy flow: Chemical PE (fuel) → thermal (combustion) → mechanical (engine) → kinetic (plane motion) → heat (air resistance). Continuous energy input from fuel exactly balances continuous energy loss to air resistance. Steady state—energy in = energy out. 

**Example 2: Object falling freely** 
• Height decreases → PE decreases ($\Delta PE = -mg\Delta h$, negative) 
• Speed increases → KE increases ($\Delta KE = +\frac{1}{2}m\Delta v^2$, positive) 
• Mechanical energy: constant if no air resistance ($PE_{\text{lost}} = KE_{\text{gained}}$) 
• Work by gravity: Positive (force down, motion down, $\theta = 0°$). $W_g = mgh$ equals KE gained. 
• Energy transformation: Gravitational PE → Kinetic energy. Total mechanical energy conserved. 

**Example 3: Airplane taking off, accelerating upward** 
• Altitude increasing → PE increasing ($\Delta PE = +mg\Delta h$, positive) 
• Speed increasing → KE increasing ($\Delta KE = +\frac{1}{2}m\Delta v^2$, positive) 
• Total mechanical energy increasing significantly (both components growing) 
• Work by engine: Large positive work (thrust force in direction of motion) 
• Work by gravity: Negative work (weight down, motion has upward component) 
• Work by drag: Negative work (opposes motion) 
• Energy source: Chemical PE in fuel → engine converts to mechanical work → increases both KE and PE of plane. Net work positive (engine work exceeds drag + gravity work). 

**Example 4: Car braking to stop** 
• Speed decreasing → KE decreasing (being removed) 
• Height constant (level road) → PE constant 
• Mechanical energy decreasing (KE lost, PE unchanged) 
• Work by friction: Negative (brakes oppose motion). $W_{\text{friction}} = -\Delta KE$ removes all kinetic energy. 
• Energy destination: KE → Heat in brake pads, rotors, tires (friction converts motion to thermal energy). Also: Some sound (brake noise), some deformation (slight wear on pads). Primarily heat—why brakes get extremely hot during hard braking. 

Understanding energy transformations answers: Why do things move? (Forces do work, transferring energy). Where does energy go? (Transforms to other forms—never disappears). How can we predict motion? (Energy conservation constrains what's possible).

image.caption: Energy scenarios: Constant KE+PE (level flight), PE→KE (falling), Increasing both (takeoff), KE→heat (braking). Energy transforms but total conserved.

sections.introduction: Different physical situations produce characteristic energy states—understanding why reveals deep insights into forces and motion.

categories.description: Both KE and PE remain constant—total mechanical energy unchanging

examples.process: Airplane at cruising altitude and speed
examples.explanation:
**Scenario**: Commercial jet at 10,000 m altitude, constant 250 m/s velocity (typical cruise). 

**Energy Analysis**: 
• PE = constant (altitude unchanging, $h = 10,000$ m stays same) 
• KE = constant (speed unchanging, $v = 250$ m/s stays same) 
• Total mechanical energy = constant 

**Why constant?** 
Forces balanced → net force = 0 → no acceleration (First Law). 
• Thrust (forward) = Drag (backward) → no horizontal acceleration → constant speed → constant KE ✓ 
• Lift (upward) = Weight (downward) → no vertical acceleration → constant altitude → constant PE ✓ 

**Work Analysis**: 
• Engine does positive work: Thrust in direction of motion, $W_{\text{engine}} = F_{\text{thrust}} \cdot d$ 
• Air resistance does negative work: Drag opposes motion, $W_{\text{drag}} = -F_{\text{drag}} \cdot d$ 
• Magnitudes equal: $W_{\text{engine}} = -W_{\text{drag}}$ (equal and opposite) 
• Net work = 0 → no change in KE (Work-Energy Theorem: $W_{\text{net}} = \Delta KE = 0$) ✓ 
• Weight and lift perpendicular to horizontal motion → do zero work on horizontal displacement 

**Energy Flow**: 
Fuel (chemical PE) → Combustion (heat) → Engine (mechanical work) → Airplane motion (maintains KE against drag) → Air friction (heat in air, sound) 
Continuous energy input (burning fuel) exactly balances continuous energy output (friction/drag losses). 
Steady state equilibrium—like water flowing into and out of bucket at equal rates (level stays constant). 

**Key Insight**: Constant energy doesn't mean no energy transfers—means transfers balanced (in = out).

**Scenario**: Satellite orbiting Earth at constant altitude (e.g., ISS at ~400 km). 

**Energy Analysis**: 
• PE = constant (orbital radius constant) 
• KE = constant (orbital speed constant—~7.7 km/s for ISS) 
• Total mechanical energy = constant (sum of KE + PE unchanging) 

**Why constant?** 
• Gravity provides exactly the centripetal force needed for circular motion at this radius and speed 
• Centripetal force perpendicular to velocity (points toward Earth, velocity tangent to orbit) 
• Perpendicular force does zero work: $W = Fd\cos 90° = 0$ 
• No work → no energy change → KE constant, PE constant (altitude constant) ✓ 

**Circular Motion Insight**: 
Centripetal force changes direction of motion but not speed. 
Direction change ≠ energy change (work requires force component along motion, not perpendicular). 
This is why: 
• Planets orbit indefinitely without fuel (no energy loss in vacuum—no air resistance) 
• Satellites can orbit for years/decades without propulsion 
• Pendulum at bottom: tension perpendicular to motion → tension does no work (only gravity does work, converting PE ↔ KE) 

**Real Complication**: 
ISS actually in very thin atmosphere → tiny air resistance → very slow energy loss. 
Must periodically fire thrusters to re-boost orbit (add energy back). 
Without this: Would gradually slow, descend, eventually burn up in atmosphere (months to years).

examples.process: Car driving on level road at constant speed
examples.explanation:
**Scenario**: Car on highway, constant 100 km/h (~28 m/s), level road. 

**Energy**: 
• PE = constant (elevation unchanging) 
• KE = constant (speed unchanging) 

**Forces and Work**: 
• Engine force (forward) = Friction + Air resistance (backward) → balanced forces 
• Engine does positive work: $W_{\text{engine}} = +F_{\text{engine}} \cdot d$ 
• Friction/drag do negative work: $W_{\text{resistance}} = -F_{\text{resistance}} \cdot d$ 
• Net work = 0 (balanced) → KE constant ✓ 

**Energy Flow**: 
Gasoline (chemical PE) → Engine (thermal → mechanical, ~28% efficient) → Drivetrain (to wheels) → Two paths: 
1. Friction in tires/bearings/drivetrain → Heat (~10-15%) 
2. Air resistance → Heat in air, sound, turbulence (~85-90% at highway speeds) 
Total: ~100% of fuel energy eventually becomes heat. 

**Why engine runs continuously?** 
Not to increase speed (constant KE)—to replace energy continuously lost to friction/drag. 
Like running on treadmill: Continuous effort to stay in same place (overcome belt friction). 
Stop engine → friction/drag remove KE → car slows → eventually stops (all KE → heat).

categories.description: Gravitational PE converts to kinetic energy—falling, sliding downhill, pendulum swing

examples.process: Object in free fall (no air resistance)
examples.explanation:
**Scenario**: Ball dropped from 20 m height. 

**Energy Changes**: 
• Initial (released): $h = 20$ m, $v = 0$. PE = max, KE = 0 
• During fall: $h$ decreasing → PE decreasing. $v$ increasing → KE increasing 
• At ground: $h = 0$, $v = ?$ (maximum). PE = 0, KE = max 
• Total mechanical energy: constant throughout (PE lost = KE gained) 

**Quantitative Analysis**: 
Mass $m = 2$ kg. 
Initial: $PE_i = mgh = 2 × 9.8 × 20 = 392$ J, $KE_i = 0$ J. Total = 392 J. 
Final: $PE_f = 0$ J, $KE_f = ?$ 
Conservation: $PE_i + KE_i = PE_f + KE_f$ 
$392 + 0 = 0 + KE_f$ → $KE_f = 392$ J 
Final speed: $KE_f = \frac{1}{2}mv_f^2$ → $392 = \frac{1}{2}(2)v_f^2$ → $v_f = \sqrt{392} ≈ 19.8$ m/s 

**Work Analysis**: 
• Gravity does work: $W_g = mgh = 392$ J (positive—force down, motion down, $\theta = 0°$) 
• This work equals KE gained: $W_g = \Delta KE = 392$ J ✓ (Work-Energy Theorem) 

**Why speed increases?** 
Gravity continuously does positive work as ball falls. 
Each meter fallen: Gravity does ~19.6 J work → adds 19.6 J to KE → speed increases. 
Acceleration constant ($g = 9.8$ m/s²), but work depends on distance fallen. 

**Energy Transformation**: 
Gravitational PE (stored energy from elevated position) → Kinetic energy (energy of motion). 
At ground impact: KE → Heat (deformation of ball and ground), Sound (impact noise), Slight permanent deformation. 
Ball bounces: Some KE → elastic PE (ball compresses) → KE again (ball rebounds). 
Each bounce loses energy to heat/sound → bounces get lower → eventually stops (all initial PE → heat/sound via multiple transformations).

**Scenario**: Coaster descends from 50 m peak to 10 m valley. 

**Energy Changes** (assuming frictionless first): 
• At peak: High PE, low KE (moving slowly at top) 
• Descending: PE decreases (height dropping), KE increases (speeding up) 
• At valley: Low PE, high KE (maximum speed at bottom) 

**Quantitative** (mass 500 kg including riders): 
Peak (50 m, 5 m/s): 
$PE = 500 × 9.8 × 50 = 245,000$ J 
$KE = \frac{1}{2}(500)(5)^2 = 6,250$ J 
Total = 251,250 J 

Valley (10 m, v = ?): 
$PE = 500 × 9.8 × 10 = 49,000$ J 
$KE = 251,250 - 49,000 = 202,250$ J 
Speed: $202,250 = \frac{1}{2}(500)v^2$ → $v ≈ 28.5$ m/s (~103 km/h) 

**With Friction** (realistic): 
Friction/air resistance do negative work → mechanical energy decreases. 
If 20% energy lost to friction during descent: 
Energy at valley = 0.8 × 251,250 = 201,000 J 
PE still 49,000 J (height determined by track) 
KE = 201,000 - 49,000 = 152,000 J 
Speed: $v ≈ 24.6$ m/s (~89 km/h)—slower due to friction 
Lost energy: 50,250 J → heat in wheels/bearings/air, sound 

**Work by Gravity**: 
Height drop: 50 - 10 = 40 m 
$W_g = mg\Delta h = 500 × 9.8 × 40 = 196,000$ J (positive work) 
This equals PE lost: $245,000 - 49,000 = 196,000$ J ✓ 
But only added 152,000 J to KE (frictionless would add 196,000 J) 
Difference: 44,000 J lost to friction during descent 

**Design Insight**: 
Coasters designed so PE at peaks converts to enough KE to climb subsequent hills. 
Must account for friction losses—can't climb back to initial height without energy input. 
First hill tallest (initial PE from chain lift), subsequent hills progressively lower (accounting for cumulative friction losses).

examples.process: Pendulum swing from release to bottom
examples.explanation:
**Scenario**: Pendulum bob (1 kg) released from 30° angle (0.2 m above lowest point). 

**Energy at Release**: 
$PE = mgh = 1 × 9.8 × 0.2 = 1.96$ J 
$KE = 0$ (released from rest) 
Total = 1.96 J 

**Energy at Lowest Point**: 
$PE = 0$ (taking lowest point as reference) 
$KE = 1.96$ J (all PE converted to KE) 
Speed: $1.96 = \frac{1}{2}(1)v^2$ → $v = 1.98$ m/s 

**Why This Happens**: 
• Gravity does positive work pulling bob downward through arc 
• String tension does zero work (always perpendicular to motion—pulls toward pivot, motion is arc) 
• Only gravity transfers energy → PE → KE transformation 

**Continuing Swing**: 
Bob passes lowest point, swings upward on other side: 
• KE → PE (slows as rises) 
• Reaches same height on opposite side (if no friction): PE = 1.96 J again, KE = 0 
• Swings back: PE → KE → PE continuously 
Energy oscillates between forms, total constant (ideal) 

**Real Pendulum** (with air resistance, pivot friction): 
Each swing loses small amount to friction/air resistance → heat/sound 
Peak height decreases slightly each swing 
Eventually stops with bob hanging straight down (all initial PE → heat/sound via many oscillations) 
Classic example of damped oscillation.

categories.description: External work adds energy, increasing both potential and kinetic simultaneously

examples.explanation:
**Scenario**: Aircraft accelerates down runway, lifts off, climbs to cruising altitude. 

**Phase 1 - Ground Roll** (0 to 100 m/s, level): 
• Altitude constant (h = 0) → PE = 0 (constant) 
• Speed increasing (0 → 100 m/s) → KE increasing 
• Engine does massive positive work accelerating plane 

**Phase 2 - Initial Climb** (100 to 150 m/s, 0 to 3000 m): 
• Altitude increasing (0 → 3000 m) → PE increasing 
• Speed still increasing (100 → 150 m/s) → KE still increasing 
• Both PE and KE increasing simultaneously 

**Quantitative** (mass 80,000 kg): 
Start of climb (100 m/s, h = 0): 
$PE = 0$ J 
$KE = \frac{1}{2}(80,000)(100)^2 = 400,000,000$ J = 400 MJ 
Total = 400 MJ 

At 3000 m altitude, 150 m/s: 
$PE = 80,000 × 9.8 × 3000 = 2,352,000,000$ J = 2352 MJ 
$KE = \frac{1}{2}(80,000)(150)^2 = 900,000,000$ J = 900 MJ 
Total = 3252 MJ 

**Energy Increase**: 
$\Delta E = 3252 - 400 = 2852$ MJ (enormous!) 

**Where This Energy Comes From**: 
Jet fuel (chemical PE) → Combustion (heat ~2500°C) → Turbine (mechanical work) → Thrust force (propels aircraft) → KE + PE of aircraft 

**Work Analysis**: 
• Engine thrust does positive work: Force has forward and upward components, motion has forward and upward components → positive work throughout 
• Gravity does negative work: Weight downward, motion has upward component during climb → $W_g = -mg\Delta h = -2352$ MJ 
• Air resistance does negative work: Opposes motion → $W_{\text{drag}} < 0$ 

**Energy Accounting**: 
Fuel energy → Engine work = Overcome gravity (add PE) + Overcome drag (heat) + Add KE (accelerate) 
Engine must provide: 2352 MJ (PE gain) + 500 MJ (KE gain) + ~1000 MJ (drag losses) ≈ 3850 MJ 
At ~28% engine efficiency: Fuel must contain ~14,000 MJ chemical energy 
Roughly 350 kg of jet fuel for this climb segment (fuel energy density ~40 MJ/kg)

**Scenario**: Rocket launches from ground, accelerates upward. 

**Energy Changes**: 
• Altitude increasing continuously → PE increasing 
• Speed increasing continuously (0 → 8 km/s for orbit) → KE increasing 
• Both increase simultaneously throughout ascent 

**Quantitative Example** (SpaceX Falcon 9 second stage, 100,000 kg including payload): 
Launch: h = 0, v = 0. PE = 0, KE = 0. Total = 0 
Orbit: h = 200 km, v = 7.8 km/s = 7800 m/s 
$PE = mgh = 100,000 × 9.8 × 200,000 = 196,000,000,000$ J = 196 GJ 
$KE = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 = \frac{1}{2}(100,000)(7800)^2 = 3,042,000,000,000$ J = 3042 GJ 
Total = 3238 GJ 

**Energy Source**: 
Rocket fuel (RP-1 kerosene + liquid oxygen) → Combustion → Exhaust velocity 
Newton's Third Law: Rocket expels exhaust backward (high KE) → Exhaust pushes rocket forward 

**Why Both Increase**: 
Rocket thrust always has upward component (adds PE) and forward component (adds KE). 
Gravity does negative work (opposes altitude gain) → reduces efficiency 
Air resistance does negative work (opposes motion) → energy loss to heat 

**Fuel Requirements**: 
To add 3238 GJ at ~65% rocket efficiency: Need ~5000 GJ from fuel 
Fuel energy density ~40 MJ/kg → Need ~125,000 kg fuel 
This is why: Rockets are mostly fuel tanks (90%+ of launch mass is propellant) 
Efficiency critical (every 1% improvement saves tons of fuel)

**Scenario**: Elevator carries 10 people (total mass 1000 kg) from ground floor to 20th floor (60 m up), accelerating at start, constant speed middle, decelerating at end. 

**Energy Changes**: 

**Phase 1 - Acceleration** (0 to 5 m/s over first 10 m): 
• Height increasing → PE increasing 
• Speed increasing → KE increasing 
• Both increase simultaneously 

Initial: h = 0, v = 0. $E = 0$ 
After acceleration: h = 10 m, v = 5 m/s 
$PE = 1000 × 9.8 × 10 = 98,000$ J 
$KE = \frac{1}{2}(1000)(5)^2 = 12,500$ J 
Total = 110,500 J 

**Phase 2 - Constant Speed** (5 m/s for 40 m): 
• Height increasing → PE increasing 
• Speed constant → KE constant 
• Only PE increases 

At top of constant speed: h = 50 m, v = 5 m/s 
$PE = 1000 × 9.8 × 50 = 490,000$ J 
$KE = 12,500$ J (unchanged) 
Total = 502,500 J 

**Phase 3 - Deceleration** (5 to 0 m/s over last 10 m): 
• Height still increasing → PE increasing 
• Speed decreasing → KE decreasing 
• PE increases more than KE decreases → net energy increase, but rate slows 

Final: h = 60 m, v = 0 
$PE = 1000 × 9.8 × 60 = 588,000$ J 
$KE = 0$ J 
Total = 588,000 J 

**Work by Motor**: 
Must provide: 588,000 J (final PE) + friction/heat losses 
If 80% efficient: Input ~735,000 J from electricity 
Takes ~20 seconds → Power ≈ 37 kW input, 29 kW useful output 

**Regenerative Systems**: 
Modern elevators can recover energy during descent: 
Descending elevator: PE → KE (accelerate down) → Electrical (motor becomes generator during braking) → Battery or back to grid 
Can recover 30-50% of lifting energy → significant electricity savings in tall buildings with high traffic

categories.description: Energy removed from system—braking while descending, controlled descent

examples.explanation:
**Scenario**: Car descending mountain road, braking to maintain safe speed. 

**Energy Changes**: 
• Altitude decreasing → PE decreasing 
• Speed decreasing (braking) → KE decreasing 
• Both PE and KE decreasing simultaneously 

**Without Braking** (dangerous): 
PE would convert to KE → speed increase uncontrollably → eventual crash 

**With Braking**: 
• Gravity does positive work (tries to accelerate car downhill) 
• Brakes do negative work (remove energy) 
• Brake work > Gravity work → net negative work → KE decreases despite PE decreasing 

**Quantitative** (1500 kg car, descending 300 m elevation over 3 km): 
Top: h = 300 m (relative to bottom), v = 60 km/h = 16.7 m/s 
$PE = 1500 × 9.8 × 300 = 4,410,000$ J = 4.41 MJ 
$KE = \frac{1}{2}(1500)(16.7)^2 = 209,000$ J = 0.21 MJ 
Total = 4.62 MJ 

Bottom: h = 0, v = 40 km/h = 11.1 m/s (slowed for safety) 
$PE = 0$ J 
$KE = \frac{1}{2}(1500)(11.1)^2 = 92,000$ J = 0.09 MJ 
Total = 0.09 MJ 

**Energy Removed**: 
$\Delta E = 0.09 - 4.62 = -4.53$ MJ (both PE and KE decreased, net huge decrease) 

**Where Did 4.53 MJ Go?** 
Brakes converted to heat: 
Brake pads and rotors absorb friction work → temperature rise (can reach 400-800°C during extended braking!) 
Heat dissipates to air via convection, radiation 
This is why: 
• Brakes smoke/glow on long descents (extreme heat) 
• Brake fade occurs (overheated brakes lose effectiveness—fluid boils, pads degrade) 
• Engine braking recommended (use transmission to slow car, spreads heat over engine cooling system instead of concentrating in brakes) 
• Runaway truck ramps exist (emergency gravel ramps—friction + uphill slope stop trucks with brake failure)

**Scenario**: Skydiver at terminal velocity (55 m/s) at 500 m altitude opens parachute, descends at new terminal velocity (5 m/s), then lands. 

**Before Parachute Opens** (terminal velocity without chute): 
• Descending at constant 55 m/s → KE constant (large) 
• Altitude decreasing → PE decreasing 
• Energy flow: PE → Heat in air (air resistance equals weight, removes PE continuously as heat) 

**Parachute Opens** (sudden increase in air resistance): 
• Massive air resistance (10-20× weight briefly) → huge negative work 
• Rapidly slows from 55 to 5 m/s in ~5 seconds 
• KE decreases rapidly (55² to 5² → 1/121 of original KE!) 
• PE still decreasing (still descending) 
• Both decreasing, but KE decrease dominates (sudden, large) 

**Quantitative** (mass 80 kg): 
At parachute deployment: h = 500 m, v = 55 m/s 
$PE = 80 × 9.8 × 500 = 392,000$ J 
$KE = \frac{1}{2}(80)(55)^2 = 121,000$ J 
Total = 513,000 J 

After parachute fully deployed: h ≈ 450 m (dropped ~50 m during deceleration), v = 5 m/s 
$PE = 80 × 9.8 × 450 = 352,800$ J 
$KE = \frac{1}{2}(80)(5)^2 = 1,000$ J 
Total = 353,800 J 

**Energy Dissipated During Deployment**: 
$\Delta E = 353,800 - 513,000 = -159,200$ J (both PE and KE decreased) 
This 159 kJ went to: 
• Heat in air (turbulence, compression, friction) 
• Sound (chute opening makes loud 'pop') 
• Parachute fabric deformation (small) 

**Landing Impact**: 
Remaining energy (353,800 J, mostly PE) dissipates on landing: 
• Legs bend → Muscles do negative work (controlled deformation) 
• Roll technique → Spreads impact over time and body area → reduces peak force 
• Energy → slight ground deformation, sound, heat in muscles/joints 

**Without Parachute** (fatal): 
All 513 kJ + PE from 500 m descent = ~900 kJ total 
Would dissipate in fraction of second on impact → enormous forces → fatal injuries 
Parachute's purpose: Spread energy dissipation over longer time and distance → survivable forces

sections.section_title: Understanding Work Done by Different Forces
sections.introduction: Different forces do different amounts and types of work. Understanding which forces do positive, negative, or zero work reveals energy transfer mechanisms.

categories.description: Gravity always points downward—work depends on vertical motion

examples.explanation:
**When**: Object moves downward (falling, rolling downhill, descending ramp) 

**Why Positive**: 
Gravity force points downward. 
Motion has downward component. 
Angle between force and displacement <90° → $\cos\theta > 0$ → positive work. 

**Formula**: 
$W_g = mg\Delta h$ (where $\Delta h$ is vertical distance descended—positive when descending) 
OR: $W_g = mgh_i - mgh_f$ (initial PE minus final PE) 

**Physical Meaning**: 
Gravity transfers energy TO object (accelerates falling object, speeds up descending car). 
Gravitational PE converts to KE (or heat if friction present). 

**Examples**: 
• Ball falling 10 m: $W_g = (2 \text{ kg})(9.8)(10) = 196$ J positive work → adds 196 J to ball's KE 
• Car rolling downhill, dropping 50 m: $W_g = (1200)(9.8)(50) = 588,000$ J → tries to accelerate car (driver brakes to prevent) 
• Water falling in hydroelectric dam: Gravity does work on water → KE → turbine → electricity

**When**: Object moves upward (thrown up, elevator rising, airplane climbing) 

**Why Negative**: 
Gravity force points downward. 
Motion points upward. 
Angle = 180° → $\cos 180° = -1$ → negative work. 

**Formula**: 
$W_g = -mg\Delta h$ (where $\Delta h$ is vertical distance climbed—negative work when climbing) 

**Physical Meaning**: 
Gravity removes energy FROM object (slows thrown ball, opposes elevator/airplane). 
KE converts to gravitational PE (ball rising loses KE, gains PE). 
OR external agent does work against gravity (elevator motor, airplane engine work against gravity to climb). 

**Examples**: 
• Ball thrown upward, rises 5 m: $W_g = -(2)(9.8)(5) = -98$ J → removes 98 J from ball's KE (slows it) 
• Elevator lifting 1000 kg up 30 m: $W_g = -(1000)(9.8)(30) = -294,000$ J → motor must overcome this negative work by gravity, doing at least +294 kJ of work 
• Rocket climbing 100 km: Gravity does enormous negative work → requires enormous fuel energy to overcome

**When**: Object moves horizontally (no altitude change) 

**Why Zero**: 
Gravity force points downward. 
Motion perpendicular (horizontal). 
Angle = 90° → $\cos 90° = 0$ → zero work. 

**Physical Meaning**: 
Gravity doesn't change object's energy during horizontal motion. 
KE constant (if no other forces). 
PE constant (altitude constant). 

**Examples**: 
• Car driving on level road: Gravity does zero work (height constant). Engine works against friction/drag only, not gravity. 
• Airplane at cruising altitude: Gravity does zero work on horizontal displacement. Engine maintains speed against drag, not gravity. 
• Satellite in circular orbit: Gravity perpendicular to velocity throughout orbit → zero work by gravity → KE constant (circular orbit constant speed) 

**Key Insight**: 
Force perpendicular to motion NEVER does work. 
This is why: 
• Can carry object horizontally with no work by gravity (gravity doesn't help or hinder horizontal motion) 
• Circular motion at constant speed possible (centripetal force perpendicular → no work → no speed change)

categories.description: Friction opposes motion—almost always does negative work

examples.explanation:
**When**: Object sliding on surface (block on table, car braking, sliding down ramp) 

**Why Always Negative**: 
Kinetic friction ALWAYS opposes motion direction. 
Angle between friction and displacement = 180° → $\cos 180° = -1$ → negative work. 

**Formula**: 
$W_f = -f_k \cdot d = -\mu_k F_N \cdot d$ (negative because opposes motion) 

**Physical Meaning**: 
Friction removes mechanical energy (KE or PE or both). 
Converts to heat (thermal energy in surfaces). 
This is dissipation—mechanical energy → thermal (irreversible process). 

**Examples**: 
• Box sliding 5 m with friction 20 N: $W_f = -20 × 5 = -100$ J → removes 100 J from KE (slows box), becomes heat in box/floor 
• Car braking (friction 6000 N) over 40 m: $W_f = -6000 × 40 = -240,000$ J → removes 240 kJ from car's KE (stops car), becomes heat in brakes (extremely hot!) 
• Block sliding down ramp with friction: Friction does negative work throughout descent → some PE converts to heat instead of KE → slower at bottom than frictionless case 

**Where Energy Goes**: 
Surfaces warm (measurable temperature increase if friction large/prolonged). 
Brake pads/rotors: Can reach 400-800°C (red hot). 
Tires: Heat from friction (why race tires soft/sticky at operating temperature). 
Bearings: Heat from friction (why they need cooling in high-speed machinery). 

**Unavoidable**: 
Can reduce friction (lubrication, smooth surfaces) but never eliminate. 
Always some energy lost to heat in real systems. 
This is why: 
• No perpetual motion (friction dissipates energy) 
• Efficiency always <100% (friction converts work to unusable heat) 
• Moving objects eventually stop without energy input (friction removes KE)

examples.process: Work by static friction (often zero or positive!)
examples.explanation:
**Special Case**: Static friction can do positive work! 

**How**: 
Static friction prevents relative motion between surfaces. 
If surfaces don't slide relative to each other, friction force can be in direction of motion. 

**Example 1 - Walking**: 
Foot pushes ground backward → Static friction on foot points forward (opposes sliding). 
Foot moves forward during step → Friction force forward, displacement forward → $\theta = 0°$ → POSITIVE work! 
Static friction does work accelerating you forward. 
Energy from: Muscles → Foot push → Ground reaction (friction) → Your KE 

**Example 2 - Car Accelerating**: 
Tire pushes ground backward (engine torque rotates wheel) → Static friction on tire points forward. 
Car moves forward → Friction force forward, displacement forward → POSITIVE work. 
Static friction accelerates car. 
Energy from: Engine → Wheel torque → Tire-road friction → Car's KE 

**Example 3 - Box on Truck Bed**: 
Truck accelerates. Box doesn't slide on bed (static friction sufficient). 
Static friction on box: Forward (prevents sliding backward). 
Box displacement: Forward (with truck). 
Friction does positive work accelerating box to match truck speed. 

**Key Insight**: 
Static friction can do positive work when it accelerates object (prevents sliding). 
Kinetic friction (sliding) ALWAYS negative work. 
The difference matters for: 
• Efficiency: Rolling friction (mostly static contact) << sliding friction 
• Traction: Static friction can accelerate vehicle; if tires slide (kinetic friction), much less force available, poor acceleration/steering 
• Energy: Static friction can transfer energy without dissipation; kinetic friction always dissipates to heat

categories.type: Work by Applied Forces (Engines, Muscles, Motors)
categories.description: External forces that do work to add energy to systems

examples.explanation:
**Car Engine Accelerating Vehicle**: 

**Mechanism**: 
Engine → Transmission → Driveshaft → Wheels → Tire-road friction → Car motion 
Engine doesn't directly push car through air. 
Engine rotates wheels, which use friction with ground to push car forward. 

**Work Analysis**: 
Engine output shaft does work rotating transmission. 
This work transfers through drivetrain to wheels. 
Static friction between tires and road does work accelerating car. 
From car's perspective: Friction force (forward) does positive work. 
From energy flow: Chemical PE (fuel) → Engine (thermal → mechanical) → Drivetrain → KE of car 

**Quantitative**: 
Accelerate 1500 kg car from 0 to 25 m/s (0 to 90 km/h): 
$\Delta KE = \frac{1}{2}(1500)(25^2) - 0 = 468,750$ J 
Engine must provide at least 469 kJ of work. 
With losses (friction in drivetrain ~15%, air resistance, rolling resistance ~10%): 
Total engine work ≈ 550 kJ 
At ~28% engine efficiency: Fuel chemical energy ≈ 2000 kJ needed. 

**On Highway** (constant speed, level road): 
Engine force = air resistance + rolling resistance (balanced). 
Work by engine = Work against air resistance + Work against rolling resistance. 
Continuous energy input (fuel) → Continuous energy output (heat in air from drag, heat in tires from rolling resistance). 
$P_{\text{engine}} = P_{\text{drag}} + P_{\text{rolling}}$ (power balance) 

**Key Principle**: 
Engine does positive work (adds energy to vehicle). 
This work either: 
(1) Increases KE (acceleration) 
(2) Increases PE (climbing) 
(3) Overcomes friction/drag (maintains speed against dissipative forces)

**Lifting Object**: 

**Mechanism**: 
Muscles contract → Tendons pull on bones → Bones rotate around joints (levers) → Hand moves upward lifting object 

**Work Analysis**: 
Muscle force: Upward component (via bones/joints). 
Displacement: Upward. 
Angle: ~0° (force and motion both upward) → Positive work. 

**Quantitative**: 
Lift 10 kg box from floor to 1.5 m shelf at constant speed: 
Force needed: $F = mg = 10 × 9.8 = 98$ N upward (constant velocity → balance weight) 
Displacement: 1.5 m upward 
Work: $W = Fd = 98 × 1.5 = 147$ J 

**Energy Flow**: 
Chemical PE (ATP in muscles, from food) → Muscle contraction (mechanical work) → Box PE (gravitational) 

**Efficiency**: 
Muscles ~20-25% efficient (lifting). 
Must expend: 147 J / 0.22 ≈ 670 J chemical energy. 
Waste: ~520 J becomes heat (why you warm up exercising). 

**During Descent** (lowering same box): 
Muscles still do positive work! 
Box wants to fall (gravity pulls down). 
Muscles prevent rapid fall by applying upward force. 
Force: Upward (slightly less than weight, so box slowly descends). 
Displacement: Downward. 
Work by muscles: Positive! (Force up, motion down, but muscles exert less than weight → net work by muscles positive? No—this is confusing.) 

**Clarification** (lowering): 
Actually, during controlled lowering: 
Gravity does positive work (down force, down motion): $W_g = +mgh$ 
Muscles do negative work (up force, down motion): $W_m = -F_{\text{muscle}} \cdot d < 0$ 
Net work: Positive (gravity work > muscle work) → object accelerates? No, because $F_{\text{muscle}}$ very close to $mg$. 
Better description: Muscles do "eccentric work" (lengthening under tension). 
Still expends energy (biochemical), but work is negative (removes energy from box, but energy goes to heat in muscles, not stored). 

**Key Point**: 
Muscles always expend chemical energy (ATP) regardless of work sign. 
Positive work (lifting): Adds mechanical energy to object. 
Negative work (lowering): Removes mechanical energy, converts to heat. 
Both processes tire muscles (biochemical energy expenditure).

**Motor Lifting Load**: 

**Mechanism**: 
Electrical energy → Magnetic forces (motor) → Rotating shaft → Pulley/gears → Lifting force 

**Work Analysis**: 
Motor output force: Upward (via cable/pulley). 
Load displacement: Upward. 
Work: Positive (force and displacement same direction). 

**Quantitative**: 
Motor lifts 500 kg load 10 m at constant 0.5 m/s: 
Force: $F = mg = 500 × 9.8 = 4900$ N 
Work: $W = Fd = 4900 × 10 = 49,000$ J 
Time: $t = d/v = 10/0.5 = 20$ s 
Power output: $P_{\text{out}} = W/t = 49,000/20 = 2450$ W = 2.45 kW 

**With Efficiency** (motor 90% efficient): 
Electrical input: $P_{\text{in}} = P_{\text{out}}/\eta = 2450/0.9 = 2720$ W = 2.72 kW 
Waste heat: $P_{\text{waste}} = 2720 - 2450 = 270$ W (motor warming) 

**Energy Flow**: 
Electrical grid → Motor (electromagnetic forces) → Mechanical work → Load PE 
90% efficient: Most electrical energy becomes mechanical work. 
10% waste: Heat in motor windings (resistance), friction in bearings. 

**Motor Lowering Load** (regenerative braking): 
Modern motors can generate electricity when lowering loads: 
Load descends: Gravity does positive work (PE → KE). 
Motor resists (controlled descent): Acts as generator. 
Mechanical work (from gravity) → Electrical energy → Battery or back to grid. 
Energy recovery: Can recapture 30-50% of PE lost during descent. 
Applications: Elevators (regenerative systems), hybrid cars (braking generates electricity), cranes (lower loads while generating power).

categories.type: Work by Normal Force and Tension
categories.description: Support forces—usually perpendicular to motion, often do zero work

examples.explanation:
**Horizontal Surface**: 
Object sliding on horizontal table. 
Normal force: Perpendicular to surface (upward). 
Displacement: Horizontal (along surface). 
Angle: 90° → $\cos 90° = 0$ → Work = 0. 

**Why Zero**: 
Normal prevents penetration into surface (provides support). 
Doesn't push forward/backward → doesn't change KE. 
Doesn't push up/down (net) → doesn't change PE (height constant). 

**Inclined Surface**: 
Object sliding down ramp. 
Normal force: Perpendicular to ramp surface. 
Displacement: Along ramp surface. 
Still 90° angle → Work = 0. 

**Circular Motion** (special case - normal CAN do work): 
Ball whirled in vertical circle on string. 
At bottom: Tension upward (normal-type force), velocity tangent to circle (horizontal). 
Angle: 90° → Work = 0 at this instant. 
BUT: As ball rises, angle between tension and velocity changes. 
Tension has component opposite to motion at some points → slight negative work. 
Overall: Tension/normal does zero work over complete circle (round trip → same speed). 

**Exception - Elevator**: 
Elevator rising at constant speed. 
Normal force (floor on person): Upward. 
Displacement (person): Upward. 
Angle: 0° → Normal does POSITIVE work! 
Work: $W_N = F_N \cdot d = mg \cdot h$ 

**Why This Isn't Really an Exception**: 
Floor and person move together (no relative motion). 
From person's perspective (standing on floor): Floor pushes up, you don't move relative to floor → zero work in person's reference frame. 
From ground's perspective: Floor pushes person up, person moves up → positive work. 
Both perspectives valid—depends on reference frame. 
Physically: Motor does work lifting elevator+person. This work increases person's PE. Normal force is mechanism transferring work from motor to person.

examples.process: Tension (usually zero work, but not always)
examples.explanation:
**Pendulum**: 
String tension always toward pivot. 
Bob velocity always tangent to arc (perpendicular to string). 
Angle: 90° throughout swing → Tension does zero work. 

**Result**: 
Tension changes direction of motion (keeps bob on circular arc). 
Tension doesn't change speed (no work → no energy change). 
Only gravity does work (PE ↔ KE transformation). 

**Towing a Car**: 
Tow rope tension: Forward (pulling direction). 
Car displacement: Forward. 
Angle: 0° → Tension does POSITIVE work. 
Work: $W_T = T \cdot d$ (tension magnitude × distance) 

**Energy Flow**: 
Towing vehicle engine → Tow rope tension → Work on towed car → KE of towed car 
Tension is force transmitting work from engine to towed vehicle. 

**Elevator Cable**: 
Cable tension: Upward. 
Elevator displacement: Upward (when rising). 
Tension does positive work: $W_T = T \cdot d$ 
This work increases elevator's PE and KE (if accelerating). 

**Pulley System**: 
Pulling rope with tension $T$ over distance $d$: 
Work input: $W_{\text{in}} = T \cdot d$ 
Load rises distance $d/n$ (where $n$ is mechanical advantage). 
Work output: $W_{\text{out}} = (nT) \cdot (d/n) = T \cdot d$ 
Same work (ideal)—pulley redistributes (force × distance conserved). 

**Key Principle**: 
Tension (like normal) is reaction force—appears as needed to maintain constraint. 
Whether tension does work depends on whether constraint allows motion in tension's direction. 
Perpendicular constraint (pendulum, circular motion): Zero work. 
Parallel constraint (towing, lifting): Positive work.

image.alt: Multiple diagrams showing different forces doing work: gravity up/down, friction (negative), engine (positive), normal (usually zero)
image.caption: Work by forces: Gravity (+ descending, - ascending, 0 horizontal), Friction (- always for kinetic), Engine/muscle (+ adds energy), Normal/tension (usually 0, perpendicular)

sections.introduction: Energy never disappears—it transforms from one form to another. Understanding transformation chains and final destinations reveals where energy ultimately goes.

categories.description: Most common transformation—friction, air resistance, deformation convert organized mechanical energy to random thermal energy

examples.explanation:
**Mechanism**: 
Sliding surfaces: Microscopic bumps collide, stick, break free. 
Each collision: KE of bulk motion → Vibration of individual atoms/molecules (thermal energy). 
Cumulative effect: Surfaces warm (measurable temperature increase). 

**Irreversibility**: 
Organized motion (all molecules moving same direction—KE) → Disorganized vibration (molecules vibrating randomly—thermal). 
Can go from organized to disorganized easily (friction). 
Cannot spontaneously reverse (heat won't reconvert to bulk motion). 
This is entropy increase—second law of thermodynamics. 

**Examples**: 

**Car Braking**: 
Initial: 1500 kg at 30 m/s. $KE = \frac{1}{2}(1500)(30)^2 = 675,000$ J 
Final: Stopped. $KE = 0$ J 
Where did 675 kJ go? → Heat in brakes. 
Temperature rise: If brake mass ~20 kg, specific heat ~500 J/(kg·°C): 
$\Delta T = Q/(mc) = 675,000/(20 × 500) = 67.5°C$ temperature rise! 
Brakes start at ~20°C → reach ~90°C (or hotter if braking harder/longer). 
Then: Heat dissipates to air (convection, radiation) → warms surrounding air slightly. 

**Meteorite Entering Atmosphere**: 
Initial: 1000 kg meteorite at 20 km/s (orbital velocity). 
$KE = \frac{1}{2}(1000)(20,000)^2 = 200,000,000,000$ J = 200 GJ 
Air resistance: Enormous friction as atmosphere compresses ahead of meteorite. 
Transformation: KE → Heat (plasma temperature 10,000+ K), Light (meteor 'shooting star'), Sound (sonic boom). 
Most meteorites: Completely vaporize (all mass converts to plasma, distributes in atmosphere). 
Tiny fraction: Slow enough to survive, land as meteorite (KE→heat in atmosphere consumed most of energy). 

**Asteroid Impact**: 
If meteorite doesn't burn up (large enough), impacts ground at high speed. 
KE → Heat (vaporizes meteorite and ground), Seismic waves (ground shock), Crater formation (deformation). 
Example: Chicxulub impact (dinosaur extinction): 10 km asteroid, 20 km/s. 
$KE \approx 10^{23}$ J (100 million megatons TNT equivalent). 
Transformation: Vaporized rock (plasma), global fires, atmospheric effects. 
Energy eventually: All becomes heat (atmosphere, ocean, ground warmed).

examples.process: Air resistance transforms mechanical energy to heat in air
examples.explanation:
**Mechanism**: 
Object moving through air: Pushes air molecules aside. 
Molecules gain KE (turbulence, compression) then lose it to collisions with other molecules. 
Result: Organized KE of object → Disorganized KE of air molecules (heat). 
Air temperature increases slightly (usually unmeasurable—large volume of air, small energy per molecule). 

**Examples**: 

**Parachutist at Terminal Velocity**: 
PE decreasing (falling): $\Delta PE = -mgh$ per second. 
KE constant (terminal velocity): No KE change. 
Energy flow: PE → Heat in air (via air resistance). 
Rate: Power = weight × velocity = $mgv$ 
For 80 kg person at 55 m/s: $P = (80)(9.8)(55) = 43,120$ W ≈ 43 kW! 
Continuously dumps 43 kW into atmosphere (heating air). 
After 60 second freefall: 43 kW × 60 s = 2.6 MJ dissipated as heat in air. 
Air volume affected: ~large (turbulent wake trail several km long). 
Temperature rise: Unmeasurable (huge volume, small energy per unit mass). 

**Spacecraft Reentry**: 
Orbital velocity: ~8 km/s. Must dissipate enormous KE to land safely. 
Shuttle mass: ~100,000 kg. $KE = \frac{1}{2}(100,000)(8000)^2 = 3.2 × 10^{12}$ J = 3.2 TJ 
Transformation: KE → Heat via air resistance (atmospheric friction). 
Heat shield: Ablative material vaporizes, carrying heat away. 
Peak heating: ~1650°C on heat shield. 
Energy rate: Megawatts during peak heating phase. 
Final: All 3.2 TJ becomes heat (heat shield ablation, air heating, some radiated to space).

categories.description: Sound is organized mechanical energy—pressure waves carrying energy through medium

examples.explanation:
**Mechanism**: 
Objects collide → Rapid compression/deformation → Creates pressure wave in air. 
Wave propagates: Alternating compression/rarefaction regions travel through air. 
Your ear: Pressure wave vibrates eardrum → perceived as sound. 

**Energy in Sound**: 
Sound waves carry energy (molecules oscillate, have KE). 
But: Very small amount compared to other transformations. 
Typical: <1% of collision energy becomes sound (rest becomes heat, deformation). 

**Examples**: 

**Clapping Hands**: 
Hands collide: KE of moving hands → compression of air between palms → sound wave. 
Hand KE: Small (maybe 1-2 J). 
Sound energy: ~0.01 J (1% of hand KE). 
Rest: Heat in hands (99%), slight stinging sensation. 
Sound disperses: Wave expands spherically, energy spreads over larger area. 
Intensity decreases: $1/r^2$ (inverse square law—farther away, quieter). 
Eventually: Sound energy absorbed by air molecules, surfaces → becomes heat (very small amount). 

**Hammer Hitting Nail**: 
Hammer KE: ~50 J (500 g hammer at 10 m/s). 
Impact: Most energy drives nail into wood (deformation work ~45 J). 
Sound: Loud 'bang' but small energy (~0.5 J, 1%). 
Heat: Nail, hammer, wood warm slightly (~4 J, 8%). 
Vibration: Nail/wood oscillate briefly, energy dissipates as heat. 

**Thunder (Lightning)**: 
Lightning heats air channel to ~30,000 K instantly. 
Superheated air expands explosively (faster than sound speed initially). 
Creates shockwave (sonic boom) → thunder. 
Energy: Lightning carries ~1-5 billion joules. 
Sound energy in thunder: ~1 million joules (~0.1% of total). 
Rest: Light (visible, UV, X-rays), heat in air, radio waves. 
Thunder sound: Disperses over km, eventually absorbed by atmosphere → heat.

**Mechanism**: 
Vibrating components create pressure fluctuations → sound waves. 
Sources: Combustion (explosions), impacts (gear teeth meshing), turbulence (air flow), resonances (panels vibrating). 

**Examples**: 

**Car Engine**: 
Combustion: Explosive expansion creates pressure pulse in cylinder. 
Exhaust opens: High-pressure gas rushes out → sound (exhaust noise). 
Engine block: Vibrates from internal forces → radiates sound. 
Power output: 100 kW typical. 
Sound power: ~100 W (0.1% of total—rest is mechanical work, heat). 
Without muffler: Much louder (1000 W sound, 1%—still small fraction). 
Muffler: Reflects, absorbs sound waves → reduces sound energy reaching outside. 
Sound energy ultimately: Absorbed by surfaces, air → becomes heat (immeasurably small temperature rise). 

**Wind Turbine**: 
Blade noise: Air turbulence at blade tips, pressure fluctuations. 
Mechanical noise: Gearbox (if present), generator. 
Power output: 2 MW typical large turbine. 
Sound power: ~200 W (0.01%—very efficient, but still audible due to low background noise in rural areas). 
Sound propagation: Travels km in quiet conditions (inverse square, but long distance). 
Regulation: Noise limits on turbine locations (residential distance requirements). 

**Jet Engine**: 
Exhaust: Turbulent mixing of high-velocity jet exhaust with ambient air → enormous sound. 
Compressor/turbine: Blade vibrations, pressure fluctuations. 
Power output: ~100 MW thrust power at takeoff. 
Sound power: ~100 kW (0.1%, but 100 kW sound is EXTREMELY loud—150+ dB near engine). 
Hearing damage: Immediate risk without protection. 
Sound energy: Disperses spherically, most absorbed by atmosphere within km → heat.

categories.description: Plastic deformation absorbs energy—metal bends, materials compress, structures crumple

examples.explanation:
**Design Purpose**: 
Crumple zones: Front/rear of car designed to deform (crush) in collision. 
Absorbs KE by doing work deforming metal (bending, folding, tearing). 
Protects occupants: Cabin stays intact (rigid), crumple zones collapse absorbing energy. 

**Energy Analysis**: 
Car mass: 1500 kg at 15 m/s (54 km/h). 
$KE = \frac{1}{2}(1500)(15)^2 = 168,750$ J ≈ 169 kJ 

Collision with wall: 
Stops in ~0.8 m (crumple zone collapses this much). 
Average force: $F = W/d = 169,000/0.8 = 211,000$ N ≈ 211 kN 
Deceleration: $a = F/m = 211,000/1500 ≈ 141$ m/s² ≈ 14g 
Time: ~0.1 seconds (calculated from $v = at$) 

**Energy Destinations**: 
• Deformation work: ~140 kJ (83%) permanently bending/crushing metal, plastic parts 
• Heat: ~20 kJ (12%) from plastic deformation (metal heats when bent permanently) 
• Sound: ~8 kJ (5%) loud crash noise 
• Vibration: ~1 kJ (<1%) car shaking after impact 

**Without Crumple Zone** (rigid car): 
Same KE to dissipate, but over ~0.05 m (much shorter distance). 
Force: $F = 169,000/0.05 = 3,380,000$ N = 3.38 MN 
Deceleration: $a ≈ 2250$ m/s² ≈ 225g (often fatal!) 
Crumple zones reduce peak force 16× (from 3.38 MN to 211 kN) by increasing stopping distance 16× (from 0.05 to 0.8 m). 
Same energy absorbed, much lower force → survivable. 

**Energy Remains in Deformation**: 
Crumpled metal stays crumpled (permanent deformation). 
Energy 'stored' in changed configuration (bent molecular bonds, dislocations in crystal structure). 
Cannot spontaneously un-crumple (irreversible). 
To repair: Must do work straightening metal (heat, hammering, replacement).

**Scenario**: Drop 5 kg weight from 2 m onto soft wood floor. 

**Energy Before Impact**: 
$PE = mgh = 5 × 9.8 × 2 = 98$ J 
$KE$ just before impact: 98 J (all PE converted) 
Velocity: $v = \sqrt{2gh} = \sqrt{2 × 9.8 × 2} ≈ 6.3$ m/s 

**Impact**: 
Weight penetrates floor ~1 cm (deformation depth). 
Work to deform floor: $W = 98$ J (must dissipate all KE). 
Average force: $F = W/d = 98/0.01 = 9,800$ N (1000× weight!) 
This force compresses wood fibers, creates dent. 

**Energy Destinations**: 
• Deformation: ~90 J (92%) compressing wood fibers, creating permanent dent 
• Heat: ~5 J (5%) from compression (wood slightly warms at impact point) 
• Sound: ~2 J (2%) impact 'thud' 
• Elastic: ~1 J (1%) weight bounces slightly (wood partially elastic), but not 100% elastic → small bounce 

**Dent Remains**: 
Wood compressed permanently. 
Energy stays in deformed configuration (compressed fibers don't spontaneously expand back—requires external work to fill/repair). 

**Harder Surface** (concrete): 
Less deformation (concrete very stiff): Maybe 0.5 mm penetration. 
Force: $F = 98/0.0005 = 196,000$ N (20,000× weight!) 
Peak force much higher → more damage to object (weight might crack/break instead of floor deforming). 
Energy distribution shifts: More to deforming weight, less to floor.

**Energy Transfer**: 
Swing hammer: Muscles do work → Hammer gains KE. 
Impact nail: Hammer KE → Work pushing nail into wood (deformation of wood). 

**Quantitative**: 
Hammer: 0.5 kg at 10 m/s. $KE = \frac{1}{2}(0.5)(10)^2 = 25$ J 
Nail penetrates: 1 cm into wood per strike. 
Work to penetrate: $W ≈ 23$ J (most of hammer KE). 
Average force on nail: $F = W/d = 23/0.01 = 2,300$ N 

**Energy Destinations Per Strike**: 
• Wood deformation: ~23 J (92%) separating fibers, compressing wood around nail shaft 
• Heat: ~1 J (4%) nail, hammer, wood warm slightly from impact 
• Sound: ~0.5 J (2%) 'bang' 
• Nail deformation: ~0.3 J (1%) nail tip flattens slightly, shaft bends if hits knot 
• Hammer rebound: ~0.2 J (<1%) elastic bounce 

**Multiple Strikes**: 
10 strikes to drive nail fully (10 cm deep). 
Total energy: 10 × 25 J = 250 J from muscles. 
Wood deformation: ~230 J permanently stored in compressed fibers around nail. 
This is why: Nail holds (friction between nail and compressed wood). 
Pulling nail out: Must overcome friction (do work separating nail from wood—partly recovers stored energy, mostly creates more damage/heat). 

**Energy Never Lost**: 
All 250 J accounted for: 
• 230 J in wood deformation (compressed fibers) 
• 10 J heat (temperature rise—immeasurable, distributed over large area) 
• 5 J sound (dispersed in air → heat) 
• 5 J various (nail deformation, hammer rebound, other losses)

categories.description: Electrical energy converts to electromagnetic radiation and heat in various devices

examples.explanation:
**Mechanism**: 
Electrical current through tungsten filament → Resistance heating → Filament glows (thermal radiation). 

**Energy Distribution** (100 W incandescent): 
Electrical input: 100 J/s (100 W) 
Outputs: 
• Infrared radiation: ~85 J/s (85 W, 85%) — heat, not visible light 
• Visible light: ~5 J/s (5 W, 5%) — actual useful output 
• Convection heat: ~10 J/s (10 W, 10%) — heats air directly 
Total: 100 J/s ✓ (energy conserved) 

**Efficiency**: ~5% (terrible!) 
95% wasted as heat (IR radiation + convection). 

**Temperature**: Filament ~2800 K to glow white-hot. 
Thermal radiation: Blackbody spectrum peaks in infrared (not visible). 
Only small portion of spectrum is visible wavelengths (400-700 nm). 
Hence low efficiency. 

**Energy Flow**: 
Electricity → Resistance heat (filament) → Radiation (mostly IR, some visible) → Absorbed by walls, objects → Heat (everything warms slightly). 
Eventually: All 100 J/s becomes heat in room. 
Even visible light: Absorbed by surfaces → heat. 
Total: 100% of electrical energy → heat (but only ~5% does useful work as light first). 

**Why Banned/Phased Out**: 
Horrible efficiency wastes electricity. 
95 J/s wasted per bulb × millions of bulbs = gigawatts wasted globally. 
Environmental: Unnecessary power generation, CO₂ emissions. 
Economic: High electricity costs for users.

**Mechanism**: 
Electrical current through semiconductor (p-n junction) → Electrons jump energy levels → Release energy as photons (light). 
Direct electrical → light conversion (not via heat). 

**Energy Distribution** (15 W LED, equivalent to 100 W incandescent): 
Electrical input: 15 J/s (15 W) 
Outputs: 
• Visible light: ~7 J/s (7 W, 47%) — much better than incandescent! 
• Heat (junction): ~8 J/s (8 W, 53%) — waste heat in LED chip 
Total: 15 J/s ✓ 

**Efficiency**: ~47% (10× better than incandescent for same light output!) 

**Why More Efficient**: 
Direct conversion: Electricity → photons (quantum process). 
No need to heat anything to thousands of degrees. 
Wavelength control: Engineer LED to emit only visible wavelengths (not wasted IR). 

**Same Light Output**: 
Incandescent: 100 W input, 5 W light → 95 W wasted. 
LED: 15 W input, 7 W light → 8 W wasted. 
Power savings: 85 W (85% reduction!) for same illumination. 

**Heat Management**: 
8 W waste heat seems small, but concentrated in tiny LED chip. 
Must dissipate via heat sink (metal fins on LED bulb base). 
Without cooling: LED overheats → efficiency drops → lifespan reduced → failure. 
This is why: LED bulbs have heat sinks (those metal ridges—not decorative, essential). 

**Energy Flow**: 
Electricity → LED (quantum emission) → 47% visible light, 53% heat. 
Light: Absorbed by surfaces → heat (eventually). 
Heat: Conducted to heat sink → radiated/convected to air. 
Final: All 15 J/s → heat in room (but after doing useful work as light first).

categories.type: Ultimate Fate: All Roads Lead to Heat
categories.description: Almost all energy transformations eventually end as low-grade thermal energy (heat)

examples.explanation:
**Universal Principle**: 
Nearly every energy transformation produces some heat (friction, resistance, inefficiency). 
Heat is 'lowest grade' energy—evenly distributed, hard to convert back to work. 
Entropy increases: Energy spreads out, becomes less useful. 

**Why Heat is Final State**: 
Heat = random molecular motion (thermal energy). 
Easy to create: Any friction, resistance, deformation → heat. 
Hard to use: Cannot convert 100% back to work (2nd law of thermodynamics—always losses). 
Spontaneously spreads: Heat flows from hot to cold (evens out—entropy increase). 

**Example Chains** (showing eventual heat): 

**Hydroelectric Dam**: 
Water PE (elevated) → KE (falling) → Mechanical rotation (turbine) → Electricity (generator) → Light (bulb) → Heat (absorbed by surfaces). 
Losses along way: Friction in turbine (heat), resistance in wires (heat), LED inefficiency (heat). 
End: 100% of original water PE → heat (in room, atmosphere, objects). 

**Car Trip**: 
Chemical PE (gasoline) → Heat (combustion) → Mechanical (engine) → KE (car motion) → Heat (braking) + Heat (air resistance) → All heat. 
Intermediate losses: Engine inefficiency (70% → heat immediately), drivetrain friction (heat), tire rolling resistance (heat). 
Even KE: Eventually dissipates to heat when braking or air resistance slows car. 
End: 100% of fuel energy → heat (engine, brakes, air, road). 

**Ball Bouncing**: 
Gravitational PE → KE (falling) → Elastic PE (compression) + Heat (deformation) → KE (bounce) → Gravitational PE (rises). 
Each bounce: Some energy → heat (inelastic collisions). 
Bounces get lower → eventually stops. 
End: All initial PE → heat (ball, floor slightly warmed—immeasurable). 

**Metabolism**: 
Chemical PE (food) → Biochemical processes → Mechanical work (muscle contraction) → Heat (75-80% immediately) + Useful work → Heat (friction, resistance). 
Even useful work (lifting object): Eventually object lowers → PE → heat. 
End: 100% of food calories → heat (body warmth, environment). 

**This is why**: 
• Universe trending toward 'heat death': All energy eventually evenly distributed as heat, no gradients to do work. 
• Efficiency matters: Slows conversion to heat, allows more useful work before inevitable heat. 
• Energy is conserved but usefulness isn't: Total energy constant, but useful energy decreases (becomes heat—hard to use). 
• We need continuous energy input (Sun): Provides high-grade energy (light), we use it, degrade to heat, radiate to space. Earth not closed system—Sun provides continuous low-entropy energy input.

image.alt: Flow diagrams showing multiple energy transformation chains, all eventually leading to heat
image.caption: Energy transformations: Mechanical → Heat (friction, collisions), → Sound (small %), → Deformation (permanent). Electrical → Light + Heat (LEDs, bulbs). All eventually → Heat (universal fate).

key_terms: Work by gravity (positive descending, negative ascending)
Work by friction (always negative for kinetic)
Work by applied forces (engines, muscles, motors)
Work by normal force (usually zero, perpendicular)
summary:
**Chapter 5 Test - Comprehensive Energy Analysis**: 

**Energy States in Different Scenarios**: 

**Constant Energy** (both KE and PE unchanging): Airplane cruising (constant altitude, constant speed), satellite in circular orbit, car at constant speed on level road. 
Why constant: Forces balanced → net force = 0 → no acceleration. Work by some forces positive, others negative → net work = 0 → no energy change. Doesn't mean no energy transfers—means continuous input exactly balances continuous output (steady state). Example: Airplane engine does positive work, air resistance does equal negative work → KE constant. 

**Decreasing PE, Increasing KE**: Free fall, roller coaster descending, pendulum swing down. 
Why: Gravity does positive work (force down, motion has downward component) → PE decreases, KE increases by equal amount (if no friction). Energy transformation: Gravitational PE → Kinetic energy. Total mechanical energy constant (conservative forces only). With friction: Some PE → heat instead of KE → slower than frictionless prediction. 

**Both PE and KE Increasing**: Airplane taking off/climbing, rocket launching, elevator ascending while accelerating. 
Why: External force (engine, motor) does large positive work → overcomes gravity (adds PE) AND adds KE (accelerates). Energy source: Chemical (fuel), electrical (motor) → Mechanical work → Both PE and KE increase. Example: Rocket—enormous fuel energy adds ~200 GJ (PE) + 3000 GJ (KE) = 3200 GJ total mechanical energy gain. 

**Both Decreasing**: Car braking while descending, parachutist landing. 
Why: Friction removes energy faster than gravity adds it → net energy decrease. Example: Car downhill—gravity does positive work (tries to accelerate), brakes do larger negative work (remove energy) → both PE and KE decrease → all dissipates as heat in brakes. 

**Work by Different Forces**: 

**Gravity**: 
• Positive work: Object descending (force down, motion has downward component). $W_g = mg\Delta h$ for vertical drop. Adds energy to object (accelerates falling object, speeds up descending car). PE → KE transformation. 
• Negative work: Object ascending (force down, motion upward). $W_g = -mg\Delta h$ for climb. Removes energy from object (slows thrown ball, opposes elevator/airplane). KE → PE transformation (or external work against gravity). 
• Zero work: Horizontal motion (force down, motion horizontal). Perpendicular → zero work. Satellite in circular orbit—gravity perpendicular to velocity throughout → no work → constant speed. 

**Friction**: 
• Kinetic friction: ALWAYS negative work (opposes motion direction). $W_f = -f_k \cdot d$. Removes mechanical energy, converts to heat. Surfaces warm, energy dissipated. Example: Braking—all KE → heat in brake pads/rotors (400-800°C possible). 
• Static friction: Can do positive work! When prevents sliding but object accelerates (walking—friction accelerates you forward; car accelerating—tire-road friction propels car). Not sliding → force can be in motion direction → positive work. 

**Applied Forces** (engines, muscles, motors): 
• Positive work: Add energy to system. Chemical/electrical → mechanical. 
• Engine: Fuel → combustion → mechanical work → increases vehicle KE and/or PE. Continuous work against friction/drag to maintain speed, or accelerate/climb. 
• Muscles: Chemical (ATP) → contraction → work lifting objects, accelerating body. ~20-25% efficient, rest becomes heat. 
• Electric motor: Electrical → mechanical. ~90% efficient. Can be reversible (regenerative braking—mechanical → electrical during lowering/braking). 

**Normal Force and Tension**: 
• Usually zero work: Perpendicular to motion. Sliding on table—normal upward, motion horizontal → zero work. Pendulum—tension toward pivot, velocity tangent → zero work. 
• Exception: When force and motion parallel. Elevator rising—normal upward, displacement upward → positive work (transmits motor work to passengers). Towing—tension forward, motion forward → positive work. 

**Energy Transformations and Destinations**: 

**Mechanical → Thermal (Heat)**: Most common. 
• Friction: Sliding surfaces → microscopic collisions → organized motion → random molecular vibration (heat). Surfaces warm. Irreversible (cannot spontaneously reverse—entropy increases). Examples: Braking (all KE → heat in brakes, can reach 90°C or higher), meteorite entry (KE → plasma heat 10,000+ K, vaporizes meteorite), spacecraft reentry (3.2 TJ KE → heat via air resistance, heat shield ablates). 
• Air resistance: Object pushes air → molecules gain KE → collisions → heat. Parachutist at terminal velocity—43 kW continuously dumped into air as heat. 

**Mechanical → Sound**: Small fraction (~1% typical). 
• Collisions: Rapid compression creates pressure wave → sound. Carries energy but very little compared to other transformations. Examples: Clapping (~0.01 J sound from ~1 J hand KE), hammer hitting nail (~0.5 J sound from ~50 J hammer KE), thunder (~1 MJ sound from ~1000 MJ lightning energy). 
• Sound eventually absorbed: Air molecules, surfaces absorb wave energy → heat (immeasurably small). 

**Mechanical → Deformation**: Permanent changes absorb energy. 
• Crumple zones: Car crash—KE → work deforming metal (~83% of crash energy). Increases stopping distance 16× → reduces peak force 16× → survivable. Energy remains in crumpled metal (permanent deformation—cannot spontaneously un-crumple). 
• Impact dents: Dropping weight → deforms floor. Energy in compressed fibers, permanent dent. 
• Hammering nail: KE → separates wood fibers, compresses wood around nail (~92% of hammer KE). Energy stored in deformation—why nail holds (friction against compressed wood). 

**Electrical → Light + Heat**: 
• Incandescent: Resistance heating → thermal radiation. 95% infrared (heat), 5% visible (terrible efficiency). Filament 2800 K, blackbody spectrum mostly IR. 
• LED: Direct quantum conversion (electricity → photons). 47% visible light, 53% heat (~10× more efficient than incandescent). Must dissipate 8 W heat from tiny chip (requires heat sink). 

**Ultimate Fate - All → Heat**: 
Nearly every transformation eventually produces heat. Heat is lowest-grade energy (random molecular motion, evenly distributed, hard to convert back to work). Examples: 
• Hydroelectric: Water PE → ... → Light → Heat (absorbed by surfaces). All original PE → heat eventually. 
• Car trip: Fuel chemical PE → ... → Heat (engine, brakes, air, road). 100% → heat. 
• Ball bouncing: PE → KE → ... → Heat (each bounce loses energy to heat, eventually stops). 
• Metabolism: Food → ... → Heat (75-80% immediately, rest eventually). Body warmth. 

**Why Heat is Final**: 
• Easy to create: Any friction, resistance → heat. 
• Hard to use: Cannot convert 100% back to work (thermodynamics—always losses). 
• Spreads naturally: Hot → cold flow (entropy increase). 
• Energy conserved but usefulness isn't: Total energy constant, useful energy decreases (degrades to heat). 

**Implications**: 
• Efficiency matters: Slows degradation to heat, extracts more useful work. 
• Continuous energy input needed: Earth receives Sun's energy (low entropy), uses it, degrades to heat, radiates to space. Not closed system. 
• Entropy increases: Universe trends toward equilibrium (all energy as evenly distributed heat—'heat death'). 

Understanding these energy transformations, work mechanisms, and final destinations completes comprehensive picture of energy in physical world—explains everything from why brakes get hot, to why cars need continuous fuel despite constant highway speed, to ultimate fate of all energy in universe.
